channel.title: philstar.com - RSS Headlines
channel.description: Philippine News for the Filipino Global Community

item.title: Life After Lockdown: Limited operations for land transport as more Filipinos hit the road
item.author: Franco Luna
item.description: (Updated) Commuters can expect long queues while waiting for their turn to board buses and trains with social distancing measures enforced under a modified lockdown scheme.

item.title: 'Don't waste quarantine sacrifices': Palace tells public to cooperate during GCQ
item.author: Alexis Romero
item.description: "As more sectors and industries begin to operate, let us continue cooperating with authorities in enforcing quarantine protocols," Roque said.

item.title: Transport sector workers seek subsidies to address reduced capacity under GCQ
item.author: Franco Luna
item.description: “Workers need to get to their jobs. Employers need their workers. The economy will suffer another blow if businesses can’t restart because their workers can’t get to the office, or the factory or if their workers get sick,” Move as One further stressed.

item.title: Most Filipinos relied on cash aid, savings and loans during quarantine — SWS
item.description: SWS found that 39% of respondents used cash assistance — including from the government’s social amelioration program —vouchers and gift certificates, among others, for their daily expenses.

item.title: Public urged to report anomalies amid COVID crisis
item.description: At both Senate health committee hearings held last May 26 and 28, Sen. Bong Go urged the public to report anomalies and corruption-related acts to authorities, especially if in connection with the purchase or selling of medical supplies and equipment amid the country’s fight against the coronavirus disease pandemic.

item.title: House OKs anti-terror bill on 1st reading
item.author: Edu Punay
item.description: The House of Representatives has passed on first reading the bill seeking to impose harsher punishment for committing terroristic acts.

item.title: All courts set to start full operations
item.author: Robertzon Ramirez
item.description: All courts and its offices will reopen beginning tomorrow, June 1, as the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Diseases eased up quarantine restrictions nationwide.

item.title: DepEd to parents: No need to buy new gadgets
item.author: Janvic Mateo
item.description: With the expected shift to alternative modes of learning in the upcoming school year, the Department of Education assured parents that there is no need to buy new gadgets as printed learning materials would be provided for those without access to technology.

item.title: Religious gatherings remain suspended
item.author: Robertzon Ramirez
item.description: Physical religious gatherings will remain suspended in general community quarantine areas to prevent the spread of the coronavirus disease 2019.

item.title: Under GCQ, still best to stay home
item.author: Romina Cabrera
item.description: The order for the public to “stay at home” remains despite the shift to a more lenient general community quarantine (GCQ) in Metro Manila tomorrow, according to a police official.
